text:
Is this allowed on the marketplace?

1. make a decent theme at an insignificant price, $1-$10 (or change the price of an existing one)
2. increase your sales greatly based on the small price, not necessarily the quality of the product, to go up in the top and gain visibility
3. set a much higher price now that you have a “successful” product (e.g., $500-$1000)

IMO, that defies the whole purpose of having a premium section and will in time just decrease the quality for customers. But if allowed, at least everybody can do it. Moreover, there is a free section. So, I don't see why would anyone set a price like that, other than increasing the number of installs and list at the top as one of the most popular paid themes. And later profit out of it by changing to a much higher price.

I don't mean to upset anyone. I'm just asking if this is allowed, so we know what to do next.

I also think that it puts the validity of the download numbers very much in question. In addition, future buyers do not know that such an action has taken place here.  Furthermore, the download number does not show how many users have reclaimed their money. A theme with 100 downloads and 40 user  asking for a refund can be qualitatively worse than a theme with 80 downloads and only 2 users who wanted their money back.

It does change the integrity of the quantitative data related to number of downloads.

A theme is able to change its price at its discretion, adjusting its price based on what they think is best, I think using this as a strategy changes the atmosphere within the marketplace.

Also <@UBT0AHWLD> from what I can tell, refunds are removed from the download total.
As far as i know, changing from Free to Paid is not allowed <@U03AKL6Q1B2>
Thank you for clarifying <@UBT0AHWLD>, I have not created a free theme and didn't notice this previously

If HubSpot is going to allow this type of market manipulation, they should put some sort of notice on download totals. 100 downloads at two dollars, two downloads at $500. There should be some sort of transparency in how the creator is manipulating the system

I do think that this should be allowed, because it’s fair for people to want to change the prices on their theme. I Also think any reviews on the theme need to be shown at what price they paid as well
that is a good idea <@U25PYL3Q8> , maybe also the number of refunds can be shown

I mean, currently I could build a theme and sell it for a dollar and install it in 100 different portals for $100, and then increase my price to $500 and we’re like oh wow 100 installs, for $100 that’s a really terrible practice, but something that could easily be done
transparency in pricing relative to downloads and reviews would add more insight for future customers
I also don’t think downloads or installs or purchases are really a good measure of if something is good or not
I feel like HubSpot should be looking at how many of those theme pages are live, that are in use.
This team has an average of seven live pages per install
basing on live pages would dramatically change the ranking for free themes
"basing on live pages would dramatically change the ranking for free themes" - which is good, or bad?
i guess good in terms of transparency, right?

I know in the old marketplace people were going from free to paid with inflated numbers. So this could be a similar tactic but using a really low price... but this kind of thing happens in Amazon Kindle books. Free book promotions boost books and then become sold. A marketplace is a dynamic place and even more so for digital goods. But another issue is people have different business models. For some, themes are a core revenue driver and others seen as a lead generation tool.

I recommend removing that metric all together as well as the sort filter for popular. You can sort by features and price.
just a statement - I'm not sure if it is good or bad - it might be better for the consumer, not so good for the themes that have downloads not being used.
I think downloads is still relevant, maybe just shouldn't be used as the determination of whether it is popular...not sure how else that would be determined.
There are also a lot of limits in place as to how a theme can be tagged and categorized, which would make it more challenging to find all of the themes that actually fit a category.

I also think there should be some minimum paid price... $7 bucks cheapens everything.

Creative Market introduced tiers for various categories.... <https://support.creativemarket.com/hc/en-us/articles/4405642917915-Minimum-Prices>
putting controls in place to limit how many times price can be changed and how dramatically might be all that is needed.

there are plenty of themes in the marketplace that show a discounted price, whether on their listing image or in the text of their listing. how to handle discounts is something that doesn't work very elegantly right now, and having a discount or promotion isn't the same thing as using it as a strategy as described in the original post
Just wait until they launch coupon codes. This will get exceptionally complicated.
